Expectation1: Maintain laboratory equipment and ensure safety protocols are followed
Situation1: A critical piece of equipment is issuing warning alerts that could lead to hazardous leakage.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: A poll worker requests that the voter re-sign a smudged envelope so the ballot will not risk rejection later.
Story: I was standing in the polling station, pen in hand, when my phone buzzed urgently in my pocket. The lab’s automated system was sending warning alerts—something was wrong with the gas chromatograph, and if the leak detector was right, there could be a hazardous situation developing. My mind raced with the protocols I’d drilled into my team: immediate shutdown, evacuation if necessary, safety above all. But here, in front of me, the poll worker was politely insisting I re-sign my ballot envelope. The signature had smudged, and if I didn’t fix it, my vote might not count. I knew the rules—no phones, no rushing, follow every instruction to the letter. My hands trembled as I tried to focus on the ballot, but my thoughts kept darting back to the lab, to the safety of my colleagues, to the possibility of disaster. I felt torn in two, the weight of civic duty pressing against the urgent responsibility of my profession, both demanding my immediate attention, both unwilling to wait.
